text:
- I'm going to let you
in on a secret recipe:
the Eriksen family seven-layer salad.
- Seven-layer salad?
Six cups of mayonnaise?
That can't be right.
- Oh, no, dear. 16 cups.
- [Babish] Hey, what's up, guys?
Welcome back to "Binging With Babish,"
where this week, we're taking a look
at the Eriksen family seven-layer salad
from "How I Met Your Mother,"

one that famously requires
16 cups of mayonnaise,
which is used almost as a mortar joint
between each layer of the salad.
We're starting with a layer

of what I assume was
store-bought guacamole,
no thicker than an inch, inch and a half,

we don't want this
salad to be too healthy,

followed by just over
two cups of mayonnaise.

Then, rinse and repeat
with each remaining layer:
bacon bits, mayo, shredded carrots, mayo,
purple cabbage, mayo, Funyuns, mayo,

gummy bears, mayo, and
of course, potato chips.

And there you have it: the
pride of the Eriksen family

and the state of Minnesota,
the seven-layer salad.

And sure, it looks beautiful,
but how's it taste?
Well, you gotta dig down deep to make sure

that you're getting a
little bit of every layer

so that you can make
an accurate assessment
when you dip that first chip.

Yep, that's what I
thought was gonna happen.

Obviously, this doesn't
taste totally awesome,

so it's gonna be pretty
easy to improve upon.
So just in time for the big game,
we're gonna make an Eriksen family twist
on a classic seven-layer dip,
first making our own refried beans,

combining two cups of beans,
a whole onion, quartered,

and two cloves of garlic
in a medium saucepan.
Cover with water, bring to a boil,
and gently simmer for 1 1/2 to 2 1/2 hours
until the beans are completely tender.
Then, strain and set aside,
reserving the bean-cooking liquid.

Meanwhile, we're cooking up
a pound of chopped bacon,
adding about 1/2 cup of water to the pan,
and letting that boil off.

This helps the bacon render
out fat more efficiently
and cook more evenly.
Strain out all that delicious bacon fat,
drain the bacon on paper towels,

and add about 1/2 cup of the
bacon fat back to the pan,
heating over medium-high until shimmering

before adding the beans with
some of the chopped-up bacon.
Why not?
Add about one cup of the bean liquid
and cook for three to five minutes

until a thick sauce
forms around the beans.
Then it's time to smash 'em up.
Use your potato masher to mash the beans
until you've reached the bean consistency
that's right for you.
Season to taste with kosher salt

and get ready for the best
refried beans of your life.
Go ahead and set those aside

until they're no longer
hot, but just warm.

Meanwhile, we're gonna
prep the other layers
of our salad dip thing,
chopping two large, ripe tomatoes

and combining with 1/4 of a
small, finely chopped red onion,

deseeded, deveined
jalapeno, finely minced,
about 1/4 cup chopped cilantro,
the juice of one particularly juicy lime,

one clove garlic, finely
chopped, pinch of kosher salt,
few twists of freshly ground black pepper,
and there you have it: pico de gallo.

Next up, as a tribute
to the perverse level
of mayo used in their recipe,
we're combining 2/3 cup of mayonnaise,
one cup of sour cream, and the juice
and zest of yet another very juicy lime,
big pinch of kosher salt.
Tiny whisk to combine, and we're left
with a sort of nod to Honduran crema.

Next up, we're preparing
some guac, carefully abiding

by all local and federal
regulations involving guacamole.

If you wanna see how to
make my favorite guacamole,

click the link in the upper
right hand corner right now.
And then it's on to assembling our dip.

First, a layer of refried
beans, followed by guacamole,

pico de gallo, shredded
cheese, shredded lettuce,
sliced jalapenos, chopped red onion,

and as a final tribute to the
Eriksens, a pile of Funyuns.

Scatter your tortilla
chips about the place
as rustically as possible,

and as with all great dips or
salads, share it with friends.
(upbeat music)
